metadata.synopsis: "Mercury Rising" stars Bruce Willis as Art Jeffries, a renegade FBI agent who combats ruthless federal agents to protect Simon (Miko Hughes), a 9-year-old autistic boy who has cracked the government's new unbreakable code. He can read MERCURY, the most advanced encryption code yet created, as easily as other kids read English. This ability renders the new billion-dollar secret code vulnerable, especially if enemies of the United States should learn of Simon's abilities and capture him.

reviews: Offers the viewer a pleasant surprise. [Full review in Spanish]
I must admit I was underwhelmed by Mercury Rising - in fact the temperature actually sank.
There's such a lack of vision behind Mercury Rising that the title could have it going in either direction and it would still end up in the same familiar place.
The actors' serious faces are out of place in this hopelessly silly action conspiracy.
This should never have been made. Avoid it and pretend it wasn't.
Baldwin's Kudrow is a one-dimensional, humorless variation on his corporate tyrant in Glengarry Glen Ross.

Fortunately, as directed with muscle and heart by Harold Becker, this tale of an angry die-hard and an orphaned autistic boy caught in a deadly government plot ranks at least as high as John McTiernan's first collaboration with an embattled Willis.
Standard action fare with a false overlay of social conscience.
The real treat is seeing Big Daddy Bruce playing the papa bear part to the little lost boy.
An anaemic time-waster you've seen before that fails to create tension or generate the suspense this genre cries out for.
The mercury may rise but pulses never do.
Serves up some dramatic moments but never legitimately convinces.
At one point, this was titled Mercury Falling, and that is a far more apt name for this ice cold thriller.
There's a lot of action but the thriller part of the movie never emerges.
The always underrated Bruce Willis manages to suggest a therapeutic process at work more on his own character's anomie and alienation than on Simon's.
Such is the not very high concept which the fitfully interesting Becker has to dumb himself down to the point of ignominy to put over.
It travels a well worn path and makes zero effort to even delve into new territory.
